Estado de New Jersey | Departmento de Servicios HumanosEsta institución es un proveedor que brinda igualdad de oportunidades.Por favor, aporte cualquier otra información que considere importante:FIRMACertifico que la información consignada es correcta y completa a mi leal saber y entender. Entiendo que, si proporcionoinformación falsa u omito alguna información que sé que es verdadera, podré estar sujeto a penalidades civiles y/openales. Podré ser deshabilitado para recibir beneficios y tendré que devolver los beneficios que recibí sin ser elegible.Entiendo que si no cambio mi PIN o reemplazo mi tarjeta, mi tarjeta actual será cancelada y se me enviará una nuevaantes del desembolso de cualquier beneficio de reemplazo.Asimismo, autorizo a la División de Desarrollo Familiar de New Jersey (DFD) y/o a la Agencia de Servicios Sociales delCondado a tratar el tema de mi reclamo de beneficios robados y divulgar la información específica del caso a cualquierorganismo policial que esté directamente involucrado en la investigación de este reclamo.Entiendo que si envío este formulario en línea, escribir mi nombre a continuación tiene el mismo efecto legal yaplicabilidad que mi firma escrita.Firma (solo si el formulario se envía por correo o en persona): Fecha:Nombre en letra de imprenta: Relacióncon elhogar:SolicitanteRepresentante autorizadoOtro:Descargue el formulario completo y devuélvalo a la Agencia de Servicios Sociales del Condado o envíelo porcorreo electrónico a: DFD.Firm@dhs.nj.gov.AGENCY USE ONLY(SOLO PARA USO DE LA AGENCIA)Date theft reported (postmark date if form mailed: Validation Method:Agency Name: Agency Worker Name (Please Print): Agency Worker Phone Number:Case Notes:Complete if telephonic signature:On at I affirm that all elements of this form were reviewed with(date) (time) (household member)who confirmed the accuracy of those elements and provided verbal consent to submit the form.Agency Worker Signature:
Estado de New JerseyDepartamento de Servicios Humanos | División de Desarrollo Familiar5/24Programa de Asistenciade Nutrición Suplementariade New JerseyPara obtener más información sobre SNAPvisit www.njsnap.govLlame al número 1-800-792-9773o llame a la Agencia de Servicios Sociales del Condado:Atlantic 609-348-3001Bergen 201-368-4200Burlington 609-261-1000Camden 856-225-8800Cape May 609-886-6200Cumberland 856-691-4600Essex 973-395-8000Gloucester 856-582-9200Hudson 201-420-3000Hunterdon 908-788-1300Mercer 609-989-4320Middlesex 732-745-3500Monmouth 732-431-6000Morris 973-326-7800Ocean 732-349-1500Passaic 973-881-0100Salem 856-299-7200Somerset 908-526-8800Sussex 973-383-3600Union 908-965-2700Warren 908-475-6301Declaración de no discriminación del USDADe acuerdo con la ley federal de derechos civiles y las normas y políticas de derechos civiles del Departamento de Agriculturade los Estados Unidos (USDA), esta entidad está prohibida de discriminar por motivos de raza, color, origen nacional, sexo(incluyendo identidad de género y orientación sexual), credo religioso, discapacidad, edad, creencias políticas, o represalia oretorsión por actividades previas de derechos civiles.La información sobre el programa puede estar disponible en otros idiomas que no sean el inglés. Personas con discapacidadque requieran medios alternos de comunicación para obtener información sobre el programa (por ejemplo, Braille, letragrande, cinta de audio, lenguaje de señas americano), debe ponerse en contacto con la agencia (estatal o local) dondesolicitaron los beneficios. Las personas sordas, con dificultades auditivas o con discapacidades del habla pueden comunicarsecon el USDA a través del Servicio Federal de Retransmisión al (800) 877- 8339.Para presentar una queja por discriminación en el programa, el reclamante debe llenar un formulario AD-3027, formulariode queja por discriminación en el programa del USDA que puede obtenerse en línea en: https://www.usda.gov/sites/default/files/documents/ad-3027s.pdf, en cualquier oficina del USDA, llamando al (833) 620-1071, o escribiendo una carta dirigidaal USDA. La carta debe contener el nombre del demandante, la dirección, el número de teléfono y una descripción escritade la acción discriminatoria alegada con suficiente detalle para informar al Subsecretario de Derechos Civiles (ASCR) sobrela naturaleza y fecha de una presunta violación de derechos civiles. El formulario AD-3027 completado o la carta debepresentarse por:(1) correro: Food and Nutrition Service, USDA1320 Braddock Place, Room 334Alexandria, VA 22314(2) fax: (833)-256-1665 o(202) 690-7442 (3) correo electrónico:fnscivilrightscomplaints@usda.govEsta institución es un proveedor que ofrece igualdad de oportunidades.
Estado de New JerseyDepartamento de Servicios Humanos | División de Desarrollo Familiar5/24Programa de Asistenciade Nutrición Suplementariade New JerseyPara obtener más información sobre SNAPvisit www.njsnap.govLlame al número 1-800-792-9773o llame a la Agencia de Servicios Sociales del Condado:Atlantic 609-348-3001Bergen 201-368-4200Burlington 609-261-1000Camden 856-225-8800Cape May 609-886-6200Cumberland 856-691-4600Essex 973-395-8000Gloucester 856-582-9200Hudson 201-420-3000Hunterdon 908-788-1300Mercer 609-989-4320Middlesex 732-745-3500Monmouth 732-431-6000Morris 973-326-7800Ocean 732-349-1500Passaic 973-881-0100Salem 856-299-7200Somerset 908-526-8800Sussex 973-383-3600Union 908-965-2700Warren 908-475-6301Declaración de no discriminación del USDADe acuerdo con la ley federal de derechos civiles y las normas y políticas de derechos civiles del Departamento de Agriculturade los Estados Unidos (USDA), esta entidad está prohibida de discriminar por motivos de raza, color, origen nacional, sexo(incluyendo identidad de género y orientación sexual), credo religioso, discapacidad, edad, creencias políticas, o represalia oretorsión por actividades previas de derechos civiles.La información sobre el programa puede estar disponible en otros idiomas que no sean el inglés. Personas con discapacidadque requieran medios alternos de comunicación para obtener información sobre el programa (por ejemplo, Braille, letragrande, cinta de audio, lenguaje de señas americano), debe ponerse en contacto con la agencia (estatal o local) dondesolicitaron los beneficios. Las personas sordas, con dificultades auditivas o con discapacidades del habla pueden comunicarsecon el USDA a través del Servicio Federal de Retransmisión al (800) 877- 8339.Para presentar una queja por discriminación en el programa, el reclamante debe llenar un formulario AD-3027, formulariode queja por discriminación en el programa del USDA que puede obtenerse en línea en: https://www.usda.gov/sites/default/files/documents/ad-3027s.pdf, en cualquier oficina del USDA, llamando al (833) 620-1071, o escribiendo una carta dirigidaal USDA. La carta debe contener el nombre del demandante, la dirección, el número de teléfono y una descripción escritade la acción discriminatoria alegada con suficiente detalle para informar al Subsecretario de Derechos Civiles (ASCR) sobrela naturaleza y fecha de una presunta violación de derechos civiles. El formulario AD-3027 completado o la carta debepresentarse por:(1) correro: Food and Nutrition Service, USDA1320 Braddock Place, Room 334Alexandria, VA 22314(2) fax: (833)-256-1665 o(202) 690-7442 (3) correo electrónico:fnscivilrightscomplaints@usda.govEsta institución es un proveedor que ofrece igualdad de oportunidades.¿Qué es SNAP?SNAP es el programa de asistencia denutrición para ayudar a las personas yfamilias de bajos ingresos a comprarlos alimentos que necesitan paracomer en forma saludable.A veces las personas siente que nodeberían necesitar ayuda para ponercomida en la mesa, pero en ciertasoportunidades tener dinero paracubrir los gastos es una lucha. Si noestá seguro de cómo va a pagar por supróxima comida o por los alimentosde la próxima semana, SNAP le puedeayudar.¿Lo sabía?• Usted puede ser elegible para SNAPincluso si es propietario de su hogaro tiene dinero en el banco.• Para ser elegible para SNAP, unapersona sola puede tener uningreso mensual bruto de $2,248.Una familia de tres puede tenerun ingreso mensual bruto de$3,833 (cifras válidas de octubre2023-septiembre 2024).• Si es elegible para SNAP, tambiénes posible que usted califique pararecibir los beneficios de ayudacon los contos de la calefacción através de Programa de Asistenciapara la Energía en Hogares deBajos Ingresos (Low IncomeHome Energy Assistance Program,LIHEAP).Programa de Asistencia de Nutrición Suplementaria de New JerseyN J S N A P¿Quiénes son elegibles?• Las personas y las familiastrabajadoras de bajos ingresos.• Las personas que recientementeperdieron sus beneficios dedesempleo.• Los trabajadores desempleados oque trabajan a tiempo parcial.• Los adultos mayores y las personascon incapacidades que cumplanlos estándares de ingresos.¿Cómo puedo presentar lasolicitud?Visite NJHelps.gov para unaevaluación previa o para presentarsu solicitud por Internet. Esta es unaforma rápida y fácil de averiguarsi va a poder recibir la ayuda. Conla presentación de la solicitud porInternet, usted dedicará menostiempo a estar en la oficina para suentrevista.* Los beneficios de SNAPse otorgan a través de la tarjetaelectrónica de beneficios “FamiliesFirst” que es muy fácil de usar.* Si no puede llegar a la Agencia de ServiciosSociales del Condado debido a unaenfermedad o discapacidad, puede enviar aun representante autorizado o solicitar unaentrevista telefónica..
Estado de New JerseyPhil Murphy, Gobernador | Sheila Oliver, VicegobernadoraDepartamento de Servicios HumanosSarah Adelman, ComisionadaLOS BENEFICIOS EXTRA DE EMERGENCIA DE SNAPTERMINARÁN EN FEBRERO DE 2023Debido a un cambio reciente en la ley federal, los beneficios temporalesadicionales que ha recibido, conocidos como Asignaciones de EmergenciaSNAP, terminarán. Esto significa que usted volverá a recibir su beneficioregular de SNAP a partir del 1 de marzo, 2023. El beneficio mensual mínimo deSNAP en New Jersey ahora es de $95.¿DÓNDE PUEDO OBTENER INFORMACIÓNDETALLADA SOBRE MI BENEFICIO?El beneficio regular y el beneficio adicional figuran porseparado. Si usted aún es elegible para recibir SNAP, sólorecibirá el beneficio regular a partir de marzo. Recibiráuna carta por correo en febrero indicando el monto de subeneficio regular, o puede:• Iniciar sesión en la aplicación móvil ConnectEBT• Visitar la página www.njfamiliesfirst.com• Llamar al número que figura en el reverso de su tarjetaEBT Families First – 1-800-997-3333¿NECESITA AYUDACON LOS RECURSOSDE ASISTENCIAALIMENTARIA?Envíe un mensaje de texto consu código postal al 898-211Visite la páginanj211.org/njsnappara obtener recursosalimentariosPóngase en contacto con suoficina local de servicios socialesVisite NJSNAP.gov¿TIENE ALGUNA PREGUNTA?SI USTED RECIBE BENEFICIOS DE ASISTENCIA ALIMENTARIA DE SNAPACTUALIZACIÓN IMPORTANTENew Jersey
Estado de New JerseyPhil Murphy, Gobernador | Tahesha Way, Vicegobernadora
Estado de New JerseyPhil Murphy, Gobernador | Tahesha Way, VicegobernadoraDepartamento de Servicios HumanosSarah Adelman, ComisionadaDatos sobre la ayuda alimentaria SNAPpara mayores de 60 años¡Aumente su presupuesto para alimentos con SNAP!Es importante saber que un hogar de SNAP serefiere a personas que viven y comen juntos,pero los adultos mayores pueden solicitar por supropia cuenta, aunque vivan con otras personas.Para la mayoría de los solicitantes, los ingresosmensuales de su unidad familiar no deben superarlos ingresos indicados en el cuadro siguiente. Sinembargo, si un miembro de la unidad familiar esmayor de 60 años o sufre una discapacidad, puedeseguir cumpliendo los requisitos aunque susingresos brutos superen estos montos.Cuando se tienen ingresos fijos, el dinero extra para comprar alimentos puede ser de granayuda. En New Jersey, el beneficio mensual mínimo de SNAP que puede recibir, si reúne losrequisitos, es de $95 - ¡eso equivale a $1,140 en dinero extra para comprar alimentos al año!Sus beneficios también pueden ser más altos si tiene gastos médicos, de vivienda y de serviciospúblicos.Solicite SNAP hoy mismo en la junta de servicios sociales de su condado o visiteNJSNAP.gov y vaya a “GET SNAP” para encontrar un navegador de SNAP.Tamaño del hogar - Ingresos brutosmensuales(octubre 2023 – septiembre 2024)1 $2,2482 $3,041Cada miembro adicional Agregar $793Si necesita ayuda solicitando, diríjase a la junta de servicios sociales de su condadoo visite NJSNAP.gov y vaya a “GET SNAP” para encontrar un Navegador de SNAP.DATOS DE SNAP PARA ADULTOS MAYORESNo hay requisito de trabajo para cualquierpersona mayor de 60 añosPuede ser elegible durante 24 mesesantes de que su caso deba ser renovadoNo es necesario ir en persona parasolicitar o completar el proceso de lasolicitud - todo se puede completar porteléfono o en línea
Estado de New JerseyPhil Murphy, Governador | Sheila Oliver, vice-governadoraDepartamento de RHSarah Adelman, ComissáriaOS BENEFÍCIOS EXTRAS DE EMERGÊNCIA DO SNAPTERMINAM EM FEVEREIRO DE 2023Devido a uma mudança recente na lei federal, os benefícios temporáriosextras que recebeu, conhecidos como Alocações de emergência doSNAP, terminam. Isso significa que receberá o seu benefício regulardo SNAP a partir de 1 de março de 2023. O benefício mensal mínimodo SNAP em New Jersey agora é de US$ 95.ONDE POSSO OBTER OS MEUS DADOSDE BENEFÍCIOS?O benefício regular e o benefício extra EA são listadosseparadamente. Se continuar qualificado para o SNAP,só receberá o seu benefício regular a partir de março.Receberá uma carta pelo correio em fevereiro indicandoo valor do seu benefício regular ou poderá:• Entrar na aplicação móvel ConnectEBT• Visitar www.njfamiliesfirst.com• Ligar para o número no verso do seu EBT FamiliesFirst Cartão 1-800-997-3333PRECISA DE AJUDACOM RECURSOSDE ASSISTÊNCIAALIMENTAR?Envie o seu código postalpara 898-211Visitenj211.org/njsnappara recursos alimentaresNew JerseyEntre em contacto como conselho local deserviços sociaisVisite NJSNAP.govTEM PERGUNTAS?SE RECEBER BENEFÍCIOS DE ASSISTÊNCIA ALIMENTAR SNAPATUALIZAÇÃO IMPORTANTEFEV
Estado de New JerseyPhil Murphy, Governador | Tahesha Way, Vice-governadoraDepartamento de Serviços HumanosSarah Adelman, ComissáriaFatos sobre assistência alimentar SNAPpara idosos com mais de 60 anosAumente seu orçamento de compras com o SNAP!É importante saber que uma família SNAP incluiqualquer pessoa que viva e faça refeições junto, masos idosos podem se candidatar por conta própria,mesmo quando viverem com outras pessoas.Para a maioria dos candidatos, o seu rendimento familiarmensal não deve ser superior aos valores indicadosna tabela abaixo. No entanto, se um membro do dafamília tiver 60 anos ou mais ou for portador de umadeficiência, poderá ainda assim ser elegível mesmoque o seu rendimento bruto exceda esses valores.Quando você tem uma renda fixa, um dinheiro a mais para comprar comida pode ser de grandeajuda! Em New Jersey, o benefício mínimo mensal do SNAP que você pode receber, se forelegível, é de US$ 95 – ou seja, US$ 1.140 em dinheiro a mais para comprar comida por ano!Seus benefícios também podem ser maiores se você tiver despesas médicas, moradia econtas de serviços públicos.Inscreva-se hoje mesmo no SNAP, no conselho de serviços sociais do seu condado, ou visiteNJSNAP.gov e acesse \

Eta New JerseyPhil Murphy, Gouvènè | Sheila Oliver, Lyetnan GouvènèDepatman Sèvis SosyalSarah Adelman, KomisyonèAVANTAJ ANPLIS SNAP AN IJANS LAN AP FINI NANMWA FEVRIYE 2023 AAkoz de chanjman ki fenk fèt nan lwa federal yo, avantaj tanporè anplis oute konn resevwa ke yo te rele Vèsman SNAP an Ijans lan ap pran fen. Savle di apati premye mas 2023, se avantaj SNAP regilye w la w ap resevwa.Avantaj minimòm pou SNAP pa mwa nan New Jersey konnya se $95.KI KOTE MWEN KA JWENN DETAY SOUAVANTAJ MWEN AN?Avantaj regilye a ak avantaj anplis EA a nan yon liski separe. Si w toujou elijib pou SNAP, w ap sèlmantoujou resevwa avantaj regilye w la apati mwa mas. Wap resevwa yon lèt nan bwat postal ou nan mwa fevriyea k ap di w montan avantaj regilye w la, oswa ou kapab:• Konekte a aplikasyon mobil ConnectEBT a• Ale sou entènèt nan www.njfamiliesfirst.com• Rele nimewo ki nan do Kat EBT Families First ou a –1-800-997-3333OU BEZWEN ÈD POUW JWENN RESOUSPOU KONEKTE W AÈD POU MANJE?Voye kòd zip ou bay898-211Ale sou entènèt nannj211.org/njsnappou w jwenn resous pou manjeNew JerseyKontakte ekip k ap jeresèvis sosyal nan zònkote w ye aVizite NJSNAP.govOU GEN KESYON?SI W GEN AVANTAJ ÈD MANJE SNAPMIZAJOU KI ENPÒTANFEVRIYE
Eta New JerseyPhil Murphy, Gouvènè | Tahesha Way, Lyetnan GouvènèDepatman Sèvis SosyalSarah Adelman, KomisèEnfòmasyon konsènan Èd Alimantè SNAPpou Granmoun ki Depase 60 lane.Ogmante Bidjè Pwovizyon ou avèk SNAP!Li enpòtan pou w konnen Fwaye SNAP la gen ladan ltout moun k ap viv epi ki manje ansanm, men moun ki ajeyo kapab aplike pou tèt yo, menmsi y ap viv ak lòt moun.Pou pifò aplikan yo, revni fwaye a chak mwa pa dwepi wo pase montan ki mansyone nan tablo ki anba a.Pakont, si manm fwaye a gen 60 lane oswa depase60 lane oswa si li gen yon andikap, yo kapab toujouelijib menmsi revni brit yo depase montan sa yo.Lè ou gen yon revni ki fiks, kèk dola anplis pou achte manje kapab yon gran èd! Nan NewJersey, minimòm avantaj SNAP ou ka resevwa chak mwa, si w elijib, se $95 - ki se $1,140 lajananplis pou w achte manje pou ane a!Avantaj ou yo ka plis si w gen frè medikal, lojman ak fakti sèvis piblik sou kont ou.Aplike pou SNAP jodi a nan konte konsèy sèvis sosyal ou a oswa vizite NJSNAP.gov epi alenan \

FRAUD ALERT: Scams Target SNAP Applicants and Recipients
FRAUD ALERT: Scams Target SNAP Applicants and Recipients\n\n\n\n\nBe aware of a scam where someone call or texts you about your SNAP case. Do not call any numbers provided and do not leave your personal information in their voicemail.\nAdditionally, be aware of other ways scammers may try to steal your benefits, including:\n\nText messages trying to get your Families First EBT card numbers or your PIN.\nA “SNAP consultant” saying you are pre-approved for SNAP or that an application was initiated on your behalf.\nSomeone helping you apply for SNAP for a fee.\n\nWe will never text you to say your card is locked or to call a number to apply or recertify, and there is never a fee to complete a SNAP application.\nIf you think a letter, phone call or text message is a scam, do not reply at all.\nThe number on your Families First card, 1-800-997-3333, is only for you to call and you will never receive a call from that number. If you receive a call from anyone claiming to be able to provide extra benefits or asking for any personal information, do not provide it.\nIf you do not know if a request for personal information is real, contact your County Social Service Agency. Personal information includes your social security number, bank information, or your Families First electronic benefits transfer (EBT) card or PIN number.\nIn addition to the County Social Service Agencies, the state works with some non-profit agencies to help New Jersey residents apply for SNAP. A full list of approved agencies that can help you apply for SNAP can be found here.\n\n\n\n Close

Families First
Families First Discovery Pass
Families First Discovery Pass\nThe New Jersey State Council on the Arts and the New Jersey Historical Commission have partnered with the NJ Departments of Human Services (DHS) and Health (DOH) to launch New Jersey’s Families First Discovery Pass program.\nThis program provides families and individuals enrolled in state assistance programs with free or highly discounted admission to arts and history organizations, venues, and programs – both in-person and virtual.\nThe Families First Discovery Pass Program offers broad access to cultural experiences for New Jersey residents and helps cultural organizations engage new audiences with the goal of building long-lasting relationships. Residents who receive benefits through SNAP, WFNJ, Child Care Assistance Program and/or WIC are eligible for free or deeply discounted cultural programs throughout the State.\nFind a list of current discounts on the Council on the Arts website here.

Families First, usted puede utilizar esos beneficios
Families FirstEBT CardUsing your New JerseyNJFamiliesFirst.com1-800-997-3333Lost, Stolen or Damaged CardsOnline ServicesIf your card has been lost, stolen or damaged,report it immediately. This will “freeze” your cardso no one can use your benefits. You can reportit and request a replacement card online atwww.NJFamiliesFirst.com, using the ConnectEBTapp, or by calling customer service at1-800-997-3333. You also can visit your CountySocial Service Agency to get a replacementcard. You may receive up to two replacementcards for free. After that, there is a fee of $2.00for each additional card.You can check your benefits, change your PIN,report a lost, stolen or damaged card and seeyour transaction history quickly and securely onlineat www.NJFamiliesFirst.com or on the ConnectEBTapp. You can set up your account either on thewebsite or the app, using the same usernameand password for both. You will need to verify youridentity when you create your account.How do I use my cardat an ATM (AutomatedTeller Machine)?If you receive Work First New Jersey cashassistance, you can get cash and check yourbalance at any ATM with the Quest® logo.Follow the ATM instructions for scanning orentering your card.• Enter your PIN.• Choose the Cash Withdrawal or Balance Inquiryoption.• Select the Checking option.• If your transaction is approved, the ATM will giveyou your cash and print a receipt.You can withdraw cash three times every monthwithout a fee. Each extra withdrawal will costyou 45¢, which will be taken out of your cashaccount. There is never a charge for balanceinquiries at an ATM.Families FirstDiscovery PassProgramYou can use your Families First EBT cardto receive free or highly discountedadmission to arts and history organizations,venues and programs throughout the stateof New Jersey. For more information anda list of participating organizations, visitwww.FamiliesFirstDiscoveryPass.com.The ConnectEBT app is free andavailable in English and Spanish.You can download it in the AppleApp Store or the Google Play Store.This institution is an equal opportunity provider.New Jersey Department of Human ServicesDivision of Family Development 4/24
Families FirstEBT CardUsing your New JerseyNJFamiliesFirst.com1-800-997-3333Lost, Stolen or Damaged CardsOnline ServicesIf your card has been lost, stolen or damaged,report it immediately. This will “freeze” your cardso no one can use your benefits. You can reportit and request a replacement card online atwww.NJFamiliesFirst.com, using the ConnectEBTapp, or by calling customer service at1-800-997-3333. You also can visit your CountySocial Service Agency to get a replacementcard. You may receive up to two replacementcards for free. After that, there is a fee of $2.00for each additional card.You can check your benefits, change your PIN,report a lost, stolen or damaged card and seeyour transaction history quickly and securely onlineat www.NJFamiliesFirst.com or on the ConnectEBTapp. You can set up your account either on thewebsite or the app, using the same usernameand password for both. You will need to verify youridentity when you create your account.How do I use my cardat an ATM (AutomatedTeller Machine)?If you receive Work First New Jersey cashassistance, you can get cash and check yourbalance at any ATM with the Quest® logo.Follow the ATM instructions for scanning orentering your card.• Enter your PIN.• Choose the Cash Withdrawal or Balance Inquiryoption.• Select the Checking option.• If your transaction is approved, the ATM will giveyou your cash and print a receipt.You can withdraw cash three times every monthwithout a fee. Each extra withdrawal will costyou 45¢, which will be taken out of your cashaccount. There is never a charge for balanceinquiries at an ATM.Families FirstDiscovery PassProgramYou can use your Families First EBT cardto receive free or highly discountedadmission to arts and history organizations,venues and programs throughout the stateof New Jersey. For more information anda list of participating organizations, visitwww.FamiliesFirstDiscoveryPass.com.The ConnectEBT app is free andavailable in English and Spanish.You can download it in the AppleApp Store or the Google Play Store.This institution is an equal opportunity provider.New Jersey Department of Human ServicesDivision of Family Development 4/24Your new FamiliesFirst EBT cardHow can I use my card?Your Families First Electronic BenefitsTransfer (EBT) card provides asafe, easy way to access yourNJ SNAP (Supplemental NutritionAssistance Program) and cashassistance benefits.Your SNAP benefits can be used to buy fooditems, such as fruits and vegetables, meat, dairyproducts, breads and cereals, snacks, or seedsand plants you can eat.Your SNAP benefits cannot be used to buyalcohol, tobacco, household items, vitamins andsupplements, or prepared food sold at the store.If you receive cash assistance benefits throughWork First New Jersey (WFNJ), you can use yourcard to purchase items not allowed by NJ SNAP.Do Not Throw Your Card Away!You will not receive a new card each month.How do I find out how muchmoney is in my NJ SNAP andcash accounts?What if I forgot or needto change my PIN?• Check your last receipt• Visit www.NJFamiliesFirst.com• Use the ConnectEBT app• Call customer service at 1-800-997-3333• Go to an ATM with theQuest® logo and selectthe Balance Inquiry option(WFNJ benefits only)If you forget your PIN or need to change it, youcan do so online at www.NJFamiliesFirst.comor on the ConnectEBT app. You can also callCustomer Service at 1-800-997-3333 or visit yourCounty Social Service Agency.To keep your benefits safe:• Never tell anyone your PIN• Do not write your PIN on your card orcardholder• Do not carry your PIN with you in your purseor wallet, where someone could find itIf someone else has access to your card andPIN and they use your benefits, your benefitswill not be replaced.Where can I use my card?Using your benefitsYou can use your card at participating stores,farmer’s markets or ATMs (WFNJ only). You can alsouse your card online for curbside pickup or deliveryat some stores. (Your benefits cannot be used topay for service or delivery tips or fees.) Look for theSNAP logo, a sign that says “EBT/SNAP acceptedhere.” Find a list of stores, including those withonline ordering on the Using Your Benefits page onwww.NJSNAP.gov.To pay with your benefits in the store, slide yourcard through the machine and choose FOOD(SNAP benefits) or CASH (WFNJ cash assistance),then enter your PIN.Families First cards may not be used to accesscash benefits at liquor stores, casinos or gamblingestablishments, or retail establishments providingadult entertainment, such as strip clubs.It is a crime to sell your card and PIN to others. Ifa violation is determined, you will pay back anybenefits obtained illegally, be disqualified from theprogram and be referred for criminal prosecution.• You will receive your benefits on the same dateat the beginning of each month.• If you do not use any of your food or cashassistance benefits for nine months, your oldbenefits will be removed from your card. Oncethe benefits are removed, they will not be replaced.• If your case closes and you still have benefits left inyour account, you can use your card until yourbalance is $0.If your SNAP and/or cash assistancebenefits were stolen electronically,you can request a replacementin certain circumstances. Visitwww.NJSNAP.gov for moreinformation.

Fatos sobre assistência alimentar SNAP
February 2023 was the last month households received at least $95 in emergency benefits or the maximum benefit for your household size, whichever is greater.Starting in March 2023, you will only receive your regular monthly benefit amount.

Federal regulations do not allow for the replacement of stolen P-EBT benefits.  If you suspect your PIN was stolen, you can call 1-800-997-3333, go to www.NJFamiliesFirst.com or download the Connect EBT app in the Apple App store or Google Play store to review your transactions and/or change your PIN to protect any remaining benefits.

Fill out an application.
Fill out an application.\nHave a phone or in-person interview In most cases, the county has 30 days after you turn in your application to determine if you will get SNAP. During the 30 days, the county will interview you. The interview will be either over the phone or in person. During the interview, the county will go over your application with you.\nSubmit verification If you are applying online, you can upload your documents online.\n\nNeed help applying? A SNAP Navigator can answer your questions and can assist with your application.  To find the agency that works in your county, visit the Get Help Applying page to view the counties each agency serves and the contact information for the agency.

Financial Resources
Financial Resources\nWork First New Jersey (WFNJ)WFNJ provides temporary cash assistance, and many other support services, to families through the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) as well as to individuals and couples without children through our General Assistance (GA) program.\nChild SupportThe child support program helps ensure financial stability for kids by helping parents establish court ordered child support, and with the collection and disbursement of child support payments.\nChild CareThe New Jersey Child Care Subsidy Program can help lower-income families who are working, in training, or a combination of these activities to pay to a portion of their child care.\nNew Jersey Career Connections\nNew Jersey Career Assistance Navigator\nNew Jersey Higher Education Student Assistance Authority

Food & Nutrition Resources
Food & Nutrition Resources\nFood PantriesFood pantries are places where people in need can access food.\nSchool Breakfast ProgramThe School Breakfast Program (SBP) provides nutritionally balanced, low-cost or no-cost breakfasts to children each school day in public and nonprofit private schools and residential child care institutions.\nSchool Lunch ProgramThe National School Lunch Program (NSLP) provides nutritionally balanced, low-cost or no-cost lunches to children each day.\nSpecial Milk ProgramThe Special Milk Program (SMP) provides milk to children in schools and child care institutions who do not participate in other federal meal service programs.\nAfter School Snack ProgramThe After school Snack Program helps children fully engage in afterschool programming by filling the hunger gap many children face in the afternoon and early evening.\nChild and Adult Care Food ProgramThe Child and Adult Care Food Program (CACFP) helps child and adult care institutions and family or group day care homes provide nutritious foods to young children, at-risk youth, and adults who are chronically impaired.\nWomen Infants & Children(WIC)WIC is a preventive public health nutrition program that provides nutrition and breastfeeding education, nutritious foods, and improved access to regular health care and social services to low and moderate-income pregnant, postpartum and breastfeeding women and young children with, or at risk of developing nutrition-related health problems.\nSenior Farmers’ Market ProgramThe Senior Farmers’ Market Nutrition Program (SFMNP) provides low-income seniors with access to locally grown fruits, vegetables, honey and herbs.\nCommodity Supplemental Food ProgramThe Commodity Supplemental Food Program (CSFP) works to improve the health of low-income elderly persons at least 60 years of age by supplementing their diets with nutritious, domestically sourced and produced food, known as USDA Foods.\nSNAP-EdNew Jersey Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program-Education (SNAP-Ed) offers information on healthy eating and active lifestyle choices.\nGood Food BucksCity Green's Good Food Buck program is a SNAP-Doubling nutrition incentive program for fruits and vegetables at farmers markets, grocery stores, and other fresh-food retailers. For every $1 you spend with your SNAP Families First EBT Card at participating locations, you receive a Good Food Bucks coupon or discount for your fresh produce purchases.\nFresh Match ProgramFresh Match is a nutritional incentive program whose goal is to increase accessibility to fresh fruits and vegetables. We provide one dollar for every dollar spent on fresh fruits and vegetables, up to ten dollars each week, to customers using a store loyalty card, a store loyalty number, and SNAP benefits on a Families First card.

Foodtown (only Foodtown locations in Monmouth County: Port Monmouth, Atlantic Highlands, Red Bank, Sea Girt, and Ocean)
For
For NJ SNAP purposes
For NJ SNAP purposes, people who live, purchase food and eat with you should be counted as household members.
For SNAP purposes your household includes anyone who purchases and prepares food together. There does not have to be any family or legal relationship to be part of the same SNAP household.
For SNAP purposes your household includes anyone who purchases and prepares food together. There does not have to be any family or legal relationship to be part of the same SNAP household. Roommates can be considered a SNAP household depending on how they buy and cook food. A person who is age 21 or younger who is living with their parent(s) must include the parent(s) in the SNAP household.
For Which Program(s) Do You Wish to Apply or Reapply?
For a list of
For example, if you are approved for $23 in SNAP benefits, you will receive an additional payment of $72 from the state so your total benefit amount is $95.
For information about eligibility for college students, visit the “Who is Eligible” section of Get SNAP on www.NJSNAP.gov.
For more SNAP information
For more information about activities, you can visit the Department of Labor’s website at www.nj.gov/labor/careerservices. There, you can schedule an appointment with your local One-Stop Career Center for personalized, one-on-one career support. Be sure to explore the website’s many other resources, including a calendar of job fairs, specific job and apprenticeship openings, special supports for groups like ex-offenders and people with disabilities, and numerous other tools to help you choose, apply for, and get a job.
For more information on New Jersey’s SNAP E&T program, contact your case worker or your County Social Service Agency.
For more information on New Jersey’s SNAP E&T program, contact your case worker or your County Social Service Agency.\nFor more information about activities, you can visit the Department of Labor’s website at www.nj.gov/labor/careerservices. There, you can schedule an appointment with your local One-Stop Career Center for personalized, one-on-one career support. Be sure to explore the website’s many other resources, including a calendar of job fairs, specific job and apprenticeship openings, special supports for groups like ex-offenders and people with disabilities, and numerous other tools to help you choose, apply for, and get a job.

French
Frequently Asked Questions
Frequently Asked Questions page
Frequently Asked Questions\n\t\t\t\t\nupdated 9/28/23\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tCan students receive SNAP? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nYes, if they meet certain conditions. In addition to the general SNAP income and other eligibility requirements, students between the ages of 18 and 49 and fit at least ONE of the following requirements to be eligible:\n\nEnrolled in an approved Career and Technical Education Programat a New Jersey community college;\nEmployed at least 20 hours per week AND paid for such work;\nParticipating in a federal work study program during the school year;\nParticipating in an on-the-job training program;\nResponsible for a household member who is a dependent under the age of six;\nA single parent enrolled full-time AND responsible for a dependent under the age 12;\nUnable to work due to a physical or mental disability; or\n\nReceiving Work First New Jersey (WFNJ) Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) benefits (cash assistance).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tWho is considered a student? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nAn institution of higher education is any public or private educational institution that requires a high school diploma or equivalency certificate for enrollment. Examples include colleges, universities, business, technical, trade and vocational schools.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tHow do I determine if my community college program is an approved Career and Technical Education Program? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nYour school’s Financial Aid Office, or the Office of the Registrar, can verify if your program of study is an approved Career and Technical Education program. The County Social Service Agency will need verification from the school to confirm that your program is approved.\nYou can download a copy of the verification form by clicking here.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tWho is part of a SNAP household? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nFor SNAP purposes your household includes anyone who purchases and prepares food together. There does not have to be any family or legal relationship to be part of the same SNAP household. Roommates can be considered a SNAP household depending on how they buy and cook food. A person who is age 21 or younger who is living with their parent(s) must include the parent(s) in the SNAP household.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tWhat are the income eligibility standards for SNAP? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nEligibility depends on several factors like income, household size, resources, etc. Below is the gross income (before taxes) eligibility standard for most households.\nGross Monthly Income Eligibility Standard\n(185% of FPL)Figures Valid October 2022 - September 2023\n\n\n\nHousehold Size\nMax. Allowable Income\n\n\n1\n$2,248\n\n\n2\n$3,041\n\n\n3\n$3,833\n\n\n4\n$4,625\n\n\n5\n$5,418\n\n\n6\n$6,210\n\n\n7\n$7,003\n\n\n8\n$7,795\n\n\nEach Add’l\n+ $793\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tHow can I find out if I’m eligible? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIf you are not sure you are eligible based on the information provided above, you can use the www.NJHelps.gov screening tool. This will also screen your eligibility for Work First New Jersey cash and health insurance (NJ FamilyCare/Medicaid).\nRemember, you must still meet one of the other student eligibility requirements listed above. Screening takes about 5-10 minutes to complete, and you will need to provide monthly income information.\nIf you are ready to apply for SNAP, you can submit an application online by clicking “Get Started” under the “Apply” header in the bottom right hand corner of www.NJHelps.gov. The online application can take 20-45 minutes to complete.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tWhat does it mean to be physically or mentally unfit for work? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nA physical or mental disability means a condition that prevents you from engaging in 20 hours of work per week. A doctor's note may be necessary to support any physical or mental limitation that may not be obvious to a county social service agency worker reviewing your application. You do not have to be participating in a federal disability program such as Social Security Disability.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tI am a college student and a single parent, can I receive SNAP? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nYes, you may be eligible if you meet the income and expense requirements and your child is living with you and is under 6 years of age.  If you are a single parent you can qualify if you meet the income and expense requirements and your child is living with you and is under 12 years of age.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tMy spouse and I are enrolled in college at the same time and we have a child under the age of 6. How does this work for us? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nOne parent can claim one child under the age of 6. If you have other children under 6, the other parent can claim that child/children for college student eligibility. If you only have one child under the age of 6, the other parent may still be eligible if they meet one of the other college student eligibility requirements listed above.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tI think I may be eligible, what should I do next? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIf you are ready to apply for SNAP, you can submit an application online by clicking “Get Started” under the “Apply” header in the bottom right hand corner of www.NJHelps.gov. You can apply in person at your County Social Service Agency - you will need to fill out an application and bring supporting documents with you.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tWhat is the application process like? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nAfter you submit an application, your County Social Service Agency will contact you to schedule an interview. Interviews may be over the phone or in person – depending on your situation. You must complete this interview. The interviewer will tell you what documents you must provide as proof of the information you stated during your application and interview. For example, proof of your identity, residency, income and who lives in your house must be provided before your application can be approved.\nIf your application is approved, you will be issued a Families First Electronic Benefits Transfer (EBT) card, which will contain your benefits.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tWhat is Work First New Jersey? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nWork First New Jersey, or WFNJ, provides cash for a limited time to low-income families, single adults and couples without children working towards self-sufficiency. There are also non-cash benefits such as short-term housing support, child care, job search and readiness assistance. New Jersey’s cash assistance program for families is known as Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF). New Jersey also has a program for single adults and couples without children, known as General Assistance (GA). You can find out more about WFNJ here.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tWhat other supports may be available to college students? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nOther supports may include cash assistance, child care, child support, health insurance and energy assistance. Visit the Department of Human Services home page for other resources.
Fresh Match Program
Fresh Match ProgramFresh Match is a nutritional incentive program whose goal is to increase accessibility to fresh fruits and vegetables. We provide one dollar for every dollar spent on fresh fruits and vegetables, up to ten dollars each week, to customers using a store loyalty card, a store loyalty number, and SNAP benefits on a Families First card.

Good Food Bucks
Good Food BucksCity Green's Good Food Buck program is a SNAP-Doubling nutrition incentive program for fruits and vegetables at farmers markets, grocery stores, and other fresh-food retailers. For every $1 you spend with your SNAP Families First EBT Card at participating locations, you receive a Good Food Bucks coupon or discount for your fresh produce purchases.

Have a phone or in-person interview In most cases, the county has 30 days after you turn in your application to determine if you will get SNAP. During the 30 days, the county will interview you. The interview will be either over the phone or in person. During the interview, the county will go over your application with you.

Hotlines and Helplines
Hourly fee
Household Size - Monthly Gross Income
Household:
Households must complete the recertification process at the end of the certification period in order to continue receiving SNAP benefits.
Households that include a senior (aged 60 and older) or people with a disability may be eligible even if their gross income exceeds the amounts in the chart above.
Households that participate in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance
Households that participate in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program and the General Assistance (GA) program can request reimbursement for benefits that were stolen electronically after July 1, 2023.
Housing & Energy Resources
Housing & Energy Resources\nEnergy Assistance ProgramsThe New Jersey Department of Community Affairs offers access to several energy assistance programs such as the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance (LIHEAP) and the Universal Service Fund (USF) programs.\nHousing Assistance ProgramsThe New Jersey Department of Community Affairs offers access to several housing assistance programs such as the State Rental Assistance Program and Housing Choice Voucher.\nNew Jersey LifelineThe Lifeline utility assistance program offers an annual utility benefit and is administered by the New Jersey Division of Aging Services.\nSNAP Utility ProgramNJ SNAP Utility Program (SNAP-UP) is an energy assistance program to help offset the cost of energy for certain SNAP households.  The SNAP-UP is not something you have to apply for; if you are eligible, you will automatically receive a $21 payment on your Families First card to be used to help you pay for your energy expenses.
Housing Assistance Programs
Housing Assistance ProgramsThe New Jersey Department of Community Affairs offers access to several housing assistance programs such as the State Rental Assistance Program and Housing Choice Voucher.
Housing costs (i.e. rent receipt, mortgage statement, property tax bills)
How Can I Apply?
How SNAP works;
How can I find out if I’m eligible?
How can I find out if I’m eligible? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIf you are not sure you are eligible based on the information provided above, you can use the www.NJHelps.gov screening tool. This will also screen your eligibility for Work First New Jersey cash and health insurance (NJ FamilyCare/Medicaid).\nRemember, you must still meet one of the other student eligibility requirements listed above. Screening takes about 5-10 minutes to complete, and you will need to provide monthly income information.\nIf you are ready to apply for SNAP, you can submit an application online by clicking “Get Started” under the “Apply” header in the bottom right hand corner of www.NJHelps.gov. The online application can take 20-45 minutes to complete.
How can I prepare for and succeed at the Employment and Training Program?
How can I prepare for and succeed at the Employment and Training Program? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to prepare for your first day:\n\nTalk to your County Social Service Agency worker about setting up child care;\nTalk to your County Social Service Agency about arranging transportation before you go;\nGet directions for your program location;\nPack a lunch;\nBring all necessary paperwork and identification.\n\nHow to succeed in employment and training:\n\nAttend every scheduled day;\nArrive on time;\nWork with your case manager to develop a plan that meets your needs and fulfills your requirements;\nTake advantage of workshops, job fairs, etc.;\nCall your program if you have problems getting there.
How can I report changes to my work status or any other updates?
How can I report changes to my work status or any other updates?  \n\n\n\n\n\n\nPhone, Mail or In-Person: You can submit your changes to your County Social Service Agency.
How can I send my documents to Quality Control?
How can I send my documents to Quality Control?\nYou should bring as much documentation as possible to your scheduled interview, but you may be asked to submit additional documentation to Quality Control.  If so, you can email, fax or mail any additional documentation needed to finish the review process. Please note, the email address below is only for submitting Quality Control documents. All other questions can be emailed to the Division of Family Development.Email (Quality Control Documents ONLY):  NJSNAPQC@dhs.nj.govFax:  (609) 588-2541Mailing Address:NJ SNAP Quality ControlPO Box 716Trenton, NJ 08610-0716
How can I use my card?
How do I determine if my community college program is an approved Career and Technical Education Program?
How do I determine if my community college program is an approved Career and Technical Education Program? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nYour school’s Financial Aid Office, or the Office of the Registrar, can verify if your program of study is an approved Career and Technical Education program. The County Social Service Agency will need verification from the school to confirm that your program is approved.\nYou can download a copy of the verification form by clicking here.
How do I find out how much
How do I find out how much money is in my NJ
How do I get to the P-EBT Benefits Search page?
How do I know if I can participate in SNAP E&T?
How do I know if I can participate in SNAP E&T? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nAre you:\n\nAt least 16 years old?\nReceiving SNAP benefits?\nNot receiving  WorkFirst New Jersey Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (WFNJ TANF)?\nWilling and able to work upon program completion?\n\nIf so, you fit the criteria and can take the next steps to connect with SNAP E&T!
How do I know if I can participate in SNAP E&T? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nAre you:\n\nAt least 16 years old?\nReceiving SNAP benefits?\nNot receiving  WorkFirst New Jersey Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (WFNJ TANF)?\nWilling and able to work upon program completion?\n\nIf so, you fit the criteria and can take the next steps to connect with SNAP E&T!\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tWhat are the benefits of participating in the E&T program? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nYou can:\n\nGain skills;\nReceive one-on-one career counseling;\nHave access to community-based partnerships;\nReceive job leads that could result in employment;          \nReceive assistance with some training and employment related fees;\nReceive reimbursement for items such as books, school supplies, transportation, uniforms and work tools; and,\nObtain industry-recognized credentials and connect with employers with in-demand jobs.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tHow can I prepare for and succeed at the Employment and Training Program? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to prepare for your first day:\n\nTalk to your County Social Service Agency worker about setting up child care;\nTalk to your County Social Service Agency about arranging transportation before you go;\nGet directions for your program location;\nPack a lunch;\nBring all necessary paperwork and identification.\n\nHow to succeed in employment and training:\n\nAttend every scheduled day;\nArrive on time;\nWork with your case manager to develop a plan that meets your needs and fulfills your requirements;\nTake advantage of workshops, job fairs, etc.;\nCall your program if you have problems getting there.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tWhat if I get a job, start a training program, or start school on my own? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nPlease let your County Social Service Agency know as soon as possible. It’s best to do this at least a couple of weeks before your first day. This will help the County Social Service Agency make sure you have the support you need on your new endeavor.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tI already have a job. Can I take advantage of the E&T program? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nAs a SNAP recipient, you can voluntarily participate in SNAP E&T, even if you are already employed! This could help you improve your skills in your current job, or start your career path in a different industry.  You can participate in these voluntary activities with no risk to your SNAP benefits. If you would like to participate in SNAP E&T or would like to learn more, please contact your County Social Service Agency.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tI want to participate in the E&T program. Can I get help paying for child care and/or transportation? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nSome expenses could be provided up-front or reimbursed through the E&T program such as transportation, child care, and items needed to participate in a work activity. These expenses are called participant allowances. They must be reasonable, necessary, and directly related to participation in the work activity. Your caseworker can help you find out what allowances are best suited for you.\nIf you need help paying for these items, please contact your County Social Service Agency and/or a representative at your work activity.\nIf you get a job while going to the E&T program, you also may be able to continue receiving reduced-cost child care through your local Child Care Resource and Referral Agency. Any out-of-pocket child care costs can be counted as an expense on your SNAP case. If you need help paying for your transportation to your job before you receive your first paycheck, you may also get transportation expenses paid until your first check. The goal is to help you keep your job, advance your career, and achieve self-sufficiency.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tI got a job through the SNAP E&T Program. What will happen to my SNAP benefits? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nCongratulations on getting a job! There are many things that determine SNAP eligibility such as your income, expenses, and household size. Your county social service agency worker will review your case and notify you about continued eligibility for SNAP.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\t\t\t\t\t\tMore Information \n\n\n\n\n\n\nFor more information on New Jersey’s SNAP E&T program, contact your case worker or your County Social Service Agency.\nFor more information about activities, you can visit the Department of Labor’s website at www.nj.gov/labor/careerservices. There, you can schedule an appointment with your local One-Stop Career Center for personalized, one-on-one career support. Be sure to explore the website’s many other resources, including a calendar of job fairs, specific job and apprenticeship openings, special supports for groups like ex-offenders and people with disabilities, and numerous other tools to help you choose, apply for, and get a job.
How do I protect my EBT
How do I use my card
How do I use my card at an Automated Teller
How do I use my card at the grocery store?
How do I use my card at the grocery store?u You can use your card at the grocery store tospend your NJ SNAP benefits.u You can also use your card at the grocery store tospend your cash benefits for items that cannot bepaid for with NJ SNAP.u At some stores, you can use your card to withdrawyour cash benefits.u Before you begin shopping, make sure the storeaccepts the card; look for the Quest ® logo inthe windows or on the doors. If you don’t see theQuest ® logo, go to thecourtesy counter and askif the store accepts theFamilies First card.u Tell the clerk that you want to use your card.u Slide your card through the machine.u Choose FOOD or CASH.u Enter your PIN on the keypad.REMEMBER: Save your receipt so that you knowyour balance the next time you go shopping.What happens if a store’s EBT machine isn’tworking?Even if a store’s EBT machines aren’t working, you maystill be able to use your card. The store cashier can usea paper voucher and call to get telephone approval foryour purchase.How do I use my card at an Automated TellerMachine (ATM)?If you are receiving a Work First New Jersey welfarecash benefit, you may get cash and check your balanceat an ATM. Look for the Quest ® logo. If you see theQuest ® logo, you can use your card at that machine.Here’s how:Follow the ATM instructions for scanning or entering yourcard.u Enter your PIN.u Choose the Cash Withdrawal or Balance Inquiryoption. (You cannot check your NJ SNAP balanceat an ATM.)u Select the CHECKING option.u If your transaction is approved, the ATM willgive you your cash and print a receipt when thetransaction is finished.u Keep your receipt and don’t forget to take your cardand your cash.You will have three free cash withdrawals everymonth. Each extra withdrawal will cost you 40¢.This fee will be taken out of your cash account.There is no charge for balance inquiries at an ATM.How do I find out how much money is in my NJSNAP and cash accounts?1. Go to www.NJFamiliesFirst.com where you canview your current card balance and transactionhistory, as well as report lost or stolen cards and viewprogram materials.2. Call Customer Service at 1-800-997-3333, whereyou can use the automated phone system to get yourbalance.3. Go to an ATM and request a balance check (not allATMs provide account balances) or check your lastreceipt. You cannot get your NJ SNAP balance at anATM, only your cash balance.Welcome to theNew Jersey EBT Program!You’re on your way to enjoying a safe and easy wayto get your NJ SNAP, formerly Food Stamps, andcash benefits.What is EBT?EBT, which stands for Electronic Benefits Transfer, is aprocess that allows you to use your Families First cardto get benefits that are deposited into an account. Yourcard is similar to a bank card and is protected with aPersonal Identification Number (PIN).Do Not Throw Your Card Away!You will not receive a new card each month.If you receive child care assistance, pleasecontact your Child Care Resource and Referral agency(CCR&R) so your Families First card (used for TANFand/or NJ SNAP) can also be used for child careservices. If you do not receive child care assistance,there is no need to call the CCR&R.
How soon are benefits available?
How soon are benefits available?\n\nWithin 30 days\nIf you need help sooner, you may qualify to receive your benefits within 7 days. If you and your household:\n\nHave less than $150 in monthly income and less than $100 in liquid resources (cash on hand, savings, or checking); or\nHave housing costs that are more than its monthly income and liquid resources; or\nYou or someone in your household is a migrant or seasonal farm worker with less than $100 in liquid resources.
How to prepare for your first day:
How to prepare for your first day:\n\nTalk to your County Social Service Agency worker about setting up child care;\nTalk to your County Social Service Agency about arranging transportation before you go;\nGet directions for your program location;\nPack a lunch;\nBring all necessary paperwork and identification.\n\nHow to succeed in employment and training:\n\nAttend every scheduled day;\nArrive on time;\nWork with your case manager to develop a plan that meets your needs and fulfills your requirements;\nTake advantage of workshops, job fairs, etc.;\nCall your program if you have problems getting there.

I Need Help Paying for Child Care
I Need Help Paying for Child Care\n\n\nLearn More

I already have a job. Can I take advantage of the E&T program?
I already have a job. Can I take advantage of the E&T program? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nAs a SNAP recipient, you can voluntarily participate in SNAP E&T, even if you are already employed! This could help you improve your skills in your current job, or start your career path in a different industry.  You can participate in these voluntary activities with no risk to your SNAP benefits. If you would like to participate in SNAP E&T or would like to learn more, please contact your County Social Service Agency.
I also authorize the New Jersey Division of Family Development (DFD) and/or the County Social Service Agency to discuss
I am a college student and a single parent, can I receive SNAP?
I am a college student and a single parent, can I receive SNAP? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nYes, you may be eligible if you meet the income and expense requirements and your child is living with you and is under 6 years of age.  If you are a single parent you can qualify if you meet the income and expense requirements and your child is living with you and is under 12 years of age.

I got a job through the SNAP E&T Program. What will happen to my SNAP benefits?
I got a job through the SNAP E&T Program. What will happen to my SNAP benefits? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nCongratulations on getting a job! There are many things that determine SNAP eligibility such as your income, expenses, and household size. Your county social service agency worker will review your case and notify you about continued eligibility for SNAP.

I think I may be eligible, what should I do next?
I think I may be eligible, what should I do next? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIf you are ready to apply for SNAP, you can submit an application online by clicking “Get Started” under the “Apply” header in the bottom right hand corner of www.NJHelps.gov. You can apply in person at your County Social Service Agency - you will need to fill out an application and bring supporting documents with you.
I understand that if I submit this form online, typing in my name below has the same legal effect and enforceability as my
I want to participate in the E&T program. Can I get help paying for child care and/or transportation?
I want to participate in the E&T program. Can I get help paying for child care and/or transportation? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nSome expenses could be provided up-front or reimbursed through the E&T program such as transportation, child care, and items needed to participate in a work activity. These expenses are called participant allowances. They must be reasonable, necessary, and directly related to participation in the work activity. Your caseworker can help you find out what allowances are best suited for you.\nIf you need help paying for these items, please contact your County Social Service Agency and/or a representative at your work activity.\nIf you get a job while going to the E&T program, you also may be able to continue receiving reduced-cost child care through your local Child Care Resource and Referral Agency. Any out-of-pocket child care costs can be counted as an expense on your SNAP case. If you need help paying for your transportation to your job before you receive your first paycheck, you may also get transportation expenses paid until your first check. The goal is to help you keep your job, advance your career, and achieve self-sufficiency.

If
If I am subject to the ABAWD Time Limit Rules, what do I have to do?
If I am subject to the ABAWD Time Limit Rules, what do I have to do? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nTo stay eligible for SNAP benefits for more than 3 months in a 3-year period, you must participate in one of the activities below on a monthly basis: \n\nSpend at least 80 hours each month doing one or more of the following activities:\n\nWorking;\nParticipating in a job program or similar activities that we approved; or\nVolunteering.\n\nParticipate in workfare for the number of hours we assigned you this month.
If I am subject to the ABAWD Time Limit Rules, what do I have to report?
If I am subject to the ABAWD Time Limit Rules, what do I have to report?  \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIf you are subject to the ABAWD Time Limit Rules, you must let us know if you are working, participating in a job program or approved activity, or volunteering for at least eighty (80) hours a month. You also must report if any of the above exemptions to the ABAWD work requirement apply to you. If you do not tell us that you are participating in work activities, or that you qualify for an exemption from the ABAWD Time Limit Rules, you will lose your SNAP benefits after 3 months.\nIf you are subject to the ABAWD Time Limit Rules and your work hours drop below 80 hours a month, you must let us know within 10 days.
If I am subject to the ABAWD Time Limit Rules, what happens if I do not meet the 80 hours requirement?
If I am subject to the ABAWD Time Limit Rules, what happens if I do not meet the 80 hours requirement? \n\n\n\n\n\n\nWe will count each full month that you receive SNAP benefits but do not meet the ABAWD Time Limit Rules without a good reason.  Once we have counted 3 full months, you will lose your benefits until January 31, 2027.
If I lose my SNAP benefits because I did not meet the ABAWD Time Limit Rules, how can I get them back?
If I lose my SNAP benefits because I did not meet the ABAWD Time Limit Rules, how can I get them back?  \n\n\n\n\n\n\nIf you start meeting the time limit rules, you can get SNAP benefits again. If something changes in your life and you no longer need to follow the ABAWD work rules (for example, you have a new physical or mental health reason for not working), you can also get SNAP benefits again. You need to report these changes to us by calling your County Social Service Agency.

If you need to replace your P-EBT card or did not receive your P-EBT card because your address was incorrect, contact your local County Social Service Agency. If your P-EBT card has been lost, stolen or damaged, it is important to immediately report it online at www.NJFamiliesFirst.com or by calling 1-800-997-3333. This will “freeze” your card so no one can use your benefits. After reporting it, contact your local County Social Service Agency for a replacement P-EBT card. You may be asked to verify your identity. There may be a fee for replacement P-EBT cards.

Il Sottoscritto riconosce/noi riconosciamo che quale criterio di idoneità al WFNJ, si richiede la registrazione al collocamento presso il New
Il Sottoscritto riconosce/noi riconosciamo che quale criterio di idoneità al WFNJ, si richiede la registrazione al collocamento presso il NewJersey One Stop Career Center.
